content.description:
The following balanced equation represents the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
<math alttext="2 H 2 O 2, aqueous, reacts to produce 2 H 2 O, liquid, plus O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>

A student carries out an experiment in which a sample of <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> decomposes in the presence of <math alttext="M n O 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>MnO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. The student measures the volume of <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> produced by the reaction at regular intervals while the temperature is held constant. The student’s data are given in the following table.
 Time (s)Volume of <math alttext="O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> Collected <math alttext="(in milliliters)" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>mL</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>60</mn></math> <math alttext="42" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>42</mn></math><math alttext="120" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>120</mn></math> <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>64</mn></math><math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll" content.question: A second experiment is done under identical conditions using a higher concentration of <math alttext="H 2 O 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in the presence of the same mass of <math alttext="M n O 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>MnO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. The volume of gas collected during the first 60 seconds will most likely be

choices.label: less than <math alttext="42 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>42</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math>
equal to <math alttext="42 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>42</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math>
greater than <math alttext="42 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>42</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math>

impossible to predict without knowing the actual concentration of <math alttext="H 2 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> used in the two experiments

content.answer: greater than <math alttext="42 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>42</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math>

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
